Hey folks, TootSDK is now public! 🚀

TootSDK is a Swift package for creating apps that interact with Mastodon, Pleroma and other Fediverse APIs.

It handles the data model and network calls, with lovely async/await based calls.

The SDK is still young. There are plenty of API calls still to add. The foundations are strong, and TootSDK is very useful already.

Contributions and PRs are more than welcome!

title: A New Drug Switched Off My Appetite. What’s Left?

last_post.content:
In my most recent column for WIRED I describe my experience with Mounjaro, a new drug for type 2 diabetics that deeply manipulates satiety, with a side effect of radical weight loss.

Fat is a vast subject involving economics, agriculture, race, gender, sexuality, cultural norms, psychology, biology, even climate. In contrast I'm relating an individual, fragmentary experience, in a state of confusion, at a moment of vulnerability. I'm sure it will go great.

title: COVID-19 Deaths in the US Continue to Be Undercounted, Despite Claims of ‘Overcounts’

last_post.content:
Other periodic reminder that the idea that COVID is "only" killing 500 people a day— like a 9/11 every [six days] is "acceptable" somehow— is generally agreed to be a gross undercount: https://www.bu.edu/sph/news/articles/2023/covid-19-deaths-in-the-us-continue-to-be-undercounted-research-shows-despite-claims-of-overcounts/

Did you know people are still misidentifying or even intentionally mislabeling cause of death wgen COVID is concerned? And that the lack of widespread free testing in official centers where results get recorded and tallied only makes that worse? And that doing things like ending the access to free AT-HOME kits will make that EVEN WORSE?

Because that should like… obvious, no?

Putting on heavy rubber gloves and boots and telling everyone the electric fence is perfectly safe; putting on suglasses at high noon and saying it's dark outside.

*Deep breath interlude*

Stuff's not over. And pretending it is and intentionally making it harder to know for sure for the sake of political expedience will only ensure we're stuck in it LONGER.

last_post.content:
I’m sad to announce that I am leaving @themarkup to pursue other projects, which I will announce soon.

It was an honor and a privilege to found @themarkup five years ago to create an investigative newsroom that integrated engineers and journalists. We showed the world what journalism could be: math literate, computationally superpowered, and human-centered.

On my departure, I thought I would reflect on the ten lessons I learned leading these investigations. https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/02/04/journalistic-lessons-for-the-algorithmic-age

title: Democrats Overhaul Party’s Primary Calendar, Upending a Political Tradition

last_post.content:
End of an era, and long overdue. Today, members of the Democratic National Committee approved a sweeping overhaul of the primary process. The Iowa caucuses will no longer lead our presidential primary calendar. Now, the process will begin with South Carolina, followed by New Hampshire and Nevada, then Georgia, and then Michigan.

@nyrath To avoid confusion here: Jourdan et al. 2023 did not measure the age of the object we know as Itokawa. They measure the time since grains in the Itokawa dust sample were hit by a ~10 gigapascal shock: https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2214353120 .

Objects like Itokawa mostly reconfigure and break up due to radiation pressure torques (the YORP effect). That is a much more gradual process and gives the current asteroid a lifetime of just ~10 million years. Per Lowry et al. 2014 - https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2014/02/aa22602-13/aa22602-13.html .

title: Scottish university press slashes open access monograph costs

last_post.content:
Although I think the Scottish University Press is an excellent initiative, I'm also worried about how these new OA book publishers are reported as being 'cheaper' than commercial publishers. It's similar to the flurry of new presses launched around the time of the RCUK policy in 2013, all claiming to undercut the price of traditional journals. Focusing on market outcomes will only benefit commercial publishers, which is exactly what happened with journal publishing and seems likely to be the effect of national OA mandates for books too.

We need to change this narrative by emphasising the community-led nature of such initiatives, the care they take in publishing, and the fact they offer an escape from marketisation not a mere rehearsal of it.

https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/scottish-university-press-slashes-open-access-monograph-costs

title: Getty Images v. Stability AI - Complaint

last_post.content:
Getty Images claims in a new lawsuit against Stability AI that output images are showing derivations of their watermark and thus violating their trademark.¹ (h/t @copyrightlately). Tangentially, this reminds me of Nintendo's strategy to stop unauthorized Game Boy publishers. The hardware checked cartridges for that iconic scrolling Nintendo logo on boot, allowing them to sue unapproved game devs who used it.² (h/t @stacksmashing)
